questions.question: What does VPN stand for?
Which of the following is a strong password?
What is two-factor authentication (2FA)?
What is the purpose of a firewall?
What does SSL stand for?
Which of the following is a type of malware?
Which of the following is the most common method of attacking a website?
What is encryption?

options.b: Scrambling data to make it unreadable

questions.question: What is a phishing attack?

options.a: Attacker sends fraudulent emails to gather sensitive information
options.b: Attacker overloads a server with requests
options.c: Attacker exploits vulnerabilities in a system

questions.question: What does 'http://' in a URL indicate?
What is a DDoS attack?
What does the CIA triad stand for?
What is a zero-day vulnerability?

options.a: A vulnerability with no fix available
options.b: A vulnerability that is patched immediately
options.c: A vulnerability found after a cyber attack

questions.question: What is social engineering in cybersecurity?

options.a: Manipulating people to gain unauthorized access to systems
options.b: Using social media to promote a product
options.c: Designing a system for high security

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a strong encryption algorithm?
What is a botnet?

options.b: A network of infected devices used to launch attacks

questions.question: Which of the following is used for secure communication over the internet?
Which of the following is the best method to protect against SQL Injection attacks?
What is a vulnerability scan?

options.a: Scanning the network for active devices
options.b: Scanning the software for performance issues
options.c: Identifying weaknesses in the system that may be exploited

questions.question: Which type of malware disguises itself as legitimate software?
What is a man-in-the-middle (MITM) attack?

options.a: Attacker intercepts and alters communication between two parties
options.b: Attacker exploits a vulnerability in the software
options.d: Attacker floods the network with traffic

questions.question: What is multi-factor authentication (MFA)?

options.a: Using a password plus one additional verification method

questions.question: What does 'salting' refer to in password security?

options.b: Encrypting the password with a unique value
options.c: Adding a random string to passwords before hashing
options.d: Using a combination of passwords and PINs

questions.question: What is the purpose of the Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML)?

options.b: To encrypt data over the internet
options.c: To verify the integrity of files

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the AES (Advanced Encryption Standard)?
What is the principle of least privilege?

options.a: Giving users the highest possible permissions
options.b: Limiting users to only the permissions they need
options.c: Giving all users the same level of access
options.d: Allowing users to escalate their privileges

questions.question: What is a rootkit?

options.a: A type of malware designed to gain administrator access
options.b: A tool used for penetration testing

questions.question: What is the main objective of the NIST Cybersecurity Framework?

options.a: To provide guidelines for financial security
options.c: To provide a set of standards for managing cybersecurity risks

questions.question: What is the purpose of an Intrusion Detection System (IDS)?

options.b: To detect and alert on malicious activity in a network

questions.question: What is the difference between symmetric and asymmetric encryption?

options.a: Symmetric encryption uses the same key for encryption and decryption, while asymmetric uses a pair of keys
options.b: Symmetric encryption is more secure than asymmetric encryption
options.c: Asymmetric encryption is faster than symmetric encryption
